headline: The Best Vegetarian Chili in the World
description: This vegetarian chili is packed with beans, corn, tomatoes, and bell peppers. Jalapeños, green chiles, and chili powder kick things up a notch!

video.description: This tasty chili is packed with healthy beans and veggies.
video.name: The Best Vegetarian Chili in the World

name: The Best Vegetarian Chili in the World
recipeIngredient: 2 (4 ounce) cans chopped green chile peppers, drained
3 (28 ounce) cans whole peeled tomatoes, crushed

recipeInstructions.text: Heat olive oil in a large pot over medium heat. Stir in onion and season with oregano, salt, cumin, and bay leaves. Cook and stir until onion is tender; stir in celery, green bell peppers, jalapeños, and garlic. Add green chile peppers and cook until heated through. Stir in vegetarian burger crumbles; reduce heat to low, cover pot, and simmer for 5 minutes.
Stir in tomatoes; season with chili powder and black pepper. Stir in kidney beans, garbanzo beans, and black beans. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to low, and simmer for 45 minutes.
Stir in the corn, and continue cooking for 5 minutes before serving.

review.reviewBody: This is the first time I made chili and my family and I loved this ! Delicious and nutritious- thank you so much

I have been making this chili since 2005. The only ingredient I leave out is the vegetarian burger crumbles. My family loves it and cannot believe that it has no meat in it. I also double the entire recipe when making it as part of a family BBQ or other gathering. I also lowered the jalapeño amount by half this time. As with any recipe those who thought it was too spicy should just reduce the hot ingredients. Thanks Jim
I used half salt, half oregano, and an extra can of beans. This still had way too much salt, oregano, and bay leaf. The flavor was good, but so strong that no one could eat more than a few bites.

Perfect every time. (But only use 1/2 -1 jalapeños depending on the size....2 is way too much). We are not vegetarian, so I usually use ground beef (cooked and seasoned with salt and pepper), but have used veggie crumbles too and either way its delicious!!

It was good and would have rated 4 stars but my vegetarian friend wished she could have more but didn't know what would fit in her calorie count. Did anyone ever find out what the portion size is? I don't wanna wade through 1.6k reviews to find out haha.

This is the best chili, vegetarian or otherwise, that I have ever made. I have made this 20 times and every time I love it. It is a bit on the thick side, so I often add a little water. I use Quorn brand veggie crumbles, and have found those to have the nicest texture, most like beef.

I don't know how this has such great reviews! I followed the recipe exactly and it really just tasted like tomatoes. No other chili recipe I've made has such a high tomatoes to other things ratio. Every other vegetarian chili I've had/made was better than this. I don't get it.
absolutely delicious! Easy to make! I portion out into individual containers and freeze. Quick easy meal at the fingertips!

made this tonight for dinner. i am not a vegetarian and would have preferred to put ground beef in this but I used 3 12oz impossible burgers chopped up instead because my spouse doesn't eat meat. I also used petite diced tomatos instead of the whole tomatoes. I did not have chile powder either. Overall I would say this was good but not the worlds best. I would make it again because my spouse enjoyed it. It was not too hot and I don't feel it was hot enough.
I have made this so many times and it is always a hit. People always ask for the recipe. I use the meatless "burger crumble" from Trader Joe's & omit the garbanzo beans.
Spicy in burn your mouth with every bite spicy. Put either jalapeno or chili's not both. Still tasty though once I got past the burning sensation.
Made exactly as recipe stated…absolutely magnificent!!
I won the office chili cook-off with this recipe! And I didn't tell anyone it was vegetarian! Very tasty
Will make again!
Made this twice but not as vegetarian chili. I used ground beef and it's delicious! This is now my go to chili recipe!

Very tasty and easy to make. I used frozen corn instead of canned but otherwise followed the recipe. I’m not a big fan of corn bead so I served it with tortilla chips for dipping. Delicious!It does make more than 8 servings.
everyone loves it!!
So amazing! I am now the default chili maker in the family lol

Fantastic recipe but made much more than 8 servings!!! I omitted the corn because someone was bringing cornbread pudding and didn’t use the bay leaves. So good - everyone enjoyed and some took some to go!
It was awesome and tasted so good. I tripled the recipe and it disappeared fast.

Delicious chili, and it keeps in the refrigerator for a full week. I use Fresh bay leaves, spicy black beans and Trader Joe's Beefless ground beef, 24 ounces. I also include frozen super sweet corn. The cumin is the "secret ingredient" to really enhance the flavor. Patty T
I love this recipe! I added zucchini, mushrooms, tomato paste, tablespoon of ketchup and some V8 juice.

I've used this recipe many times and it's delicious. I follow the recipe, but I do use the reduced or no sodium beans/tomatoes because the salt intake here is insane. You can always add more salt later. I also let it simmer for a few hours on low heat for a few hours covered, stirring occasionally. Everyone I've served this to loves it, including the meat eaters. Total winner here!

Thought that this was a great foundation to use. I have omitted as well as utilized alternatives with vegetables and spices. Not particularly a fan of corn in chili so I diced up petite turnips instead, which makes it a bit robust I think. Being a huge fan of spices, decided to sauté the cumin and paprika with the onions as well as add more cumin as it slowly simmers.
Quite tasty and filling

Very tasty! It makes a lot of chili—about 6 quarts. If you are using jalapeños, DONT use ribs or seeds or it will be very spicy indeed. You can sub habanero’s 1:1 with the same direction about ribs and seeds. I like double onion and double garlic on this btw.

I made this exactly as stated EXCEPT I left out the crumbles ( didn't have any, plus they aren't necessary) and the fresh chiles-- one can of chiles made it hot enough for me! Great recipe, easy and I had all the ingredients on hand. made great lunch for the week, low cal but filling.

Wow!! Tweaked as we all do. A little less heat. One hot pepper, 1 tablespoon chili powder. Special note though. My vegan daughter, meat loving husband, picky grandsons ate this like it was their favorite meal ever. Rave reviews all through dinner. I put it in my 6quart crock pot and it filled it. Fed 10. Made with “beyond beef” one I cooked with taco seasoning before I added. Special place in the rotation.

I made a few changes: only 1 T vs 1/4 cup of chili powder—way too much & could barely tolerate 1 T and 1 t; no jalapeños, 4 vs 2 stalks of celery, added 1 cup of cut carrots, used yellow, orange and red peppers for 1 of the 2 green peppers; added 2 bay leaves, no burger crumbles—my family doesn’t fall for it; pinto vs garbanzo beans, rinsed all beans, used 2 vs 1 can of corn and used 50% less sodium DelMonte, but maybe just 1 next time; and 3 cans of tomatoes were too much—last time I did on 2 and 1 can of diced tomatoes with chili.
added a half pound lean ground beef, 6 fresh poblano chilis instead of canned green chilis and jalapenos, used frozen fresh tomatoes and broth instead of canned tomatoes and frozen corn.

This is the BEST chili I’ve ever had, and definitely one of the best vegetarian meals I’ve ever made. It’s a staple in my house now, we’ve made it many times over the last few years as-is and there’s enough left overs that I give some to my sister and we bring it to work for days. 
For people that say it’s too spicy———-really?? I added habaneros and doubled the jalapeño too last time. It’s got a lot of good flavor, but if you simmer it long enough and follow the recipe it’s just AMAZING.

Great chili starter! However, I did Great Value Mixed Chili Beans , Chili-Fixin style Rotel for my tomatoes, & added Vegetable broth for my liquid. Oh, my Impossible meat, 1 Regular & 1 Spicy sausage was to die for! I used everything else that recipe called for except celery & corn just wasn't feeling it. Definitely a keeper! Making it again this weekend. Pot from yesterday will be gone as cold weather moves through Texas.
I made this twice. First time I followed the recipe. It’s was good,
Very good. We leave out the fake beef crumbles, as it really doesn't need it, and when I eat vegetarian, I am not looking for a meat substitute, but a veg-heavy meal.
Did not make as hot as directed and it was so good. Will make again!

I make this chili all the time and it always gets rave reviews. It is my go-to for potlucks because I like to make sure there is something yummy for the vegetarians to eat that isn't just a salad or veggie tray. The only change I consistently make is adding more cumin. I LOVE cumin and I don't think this recipe uses quite enough. I've made various changes in the beans depending on what I have at home, but it always turns out well.

Made this recipe x4 in a huge pot and guess what, WE GOT 3RD PLACE AT THE CHILI COOKOFF!!! 
I didn't measure any spices, just went by taste and it turned out wonderful! Hip-hip-hooray for vegetarian chili!!!
Photo as evidence!
Made this tonight exactly as written. I was great! Will definetly make again. Leftovers into the Souper Cubes, then vacuum sealed.
So goood!! Cold weather staple in my house for the last 2 years.

I’ve made this several times. I now make my own blend of chili powders just for fun and switch up some of the ingredients now and then. It’s an excellent fast, easy and delicious recipe- and we’re not even vegetarian :)
I did this so many times, first for a person who was veg. And she loved it. Then I did it for other people. You can't tell if the chilli is meat or not. YUM!

This fit the bill in my quest for Meatless Monday! My husband suffered a heart attack in June 2021, altering my cooking forever! I used Cento whole tomatoes (check your favorite whole tomatoes, you will be shocked at the difference in sodium between whole, diced, crushed, sauce and paste!) No-salt beans, regular canned green chilis, Quorn crumbles, and fresh or frozen everything else for a sodium total of 985 mg for a 1/2 recipe, probably serves 6 (?). THAT is AWESOME! 5 stars all the way!

I didn't use any meat at all and subbed two cans of pureed tomatoes and one can of water. It was good, probably a bit too "tomatoey" but that was my choice. Everyone ate it and seemed to enjoy it; I will make this recipe again--following the directions!

Great recipe and, though I see at least one person found this too spicy (I can't help think that the person who wrote that used another kind of pepper. See my note at the bottom). I found the heat just right. Overall, the recipe has loads of flavor, texture and looks pretty too! I did use a bit less salt than called for (using 2 teaspoons rather than 1T). I like salty food, and this reduction did not leave me wanting to add more. I also used sweet peppers of different colors (red and yellow) which added more color. The prep time @ 15 minutes is, I believe, a bit optimistic for the first time you make this - there is a lot to chop. But, it's well worth it. *Warning, if you substitute serrano peppers for jalapenos, know they pack MUCH more heat! Use 1/9th the quantity of serrano than jalapeno, and wear gloves! I caught the proportion issue in the nick of time. But, unfortunately, didn't think to use gloves and my hands still sting the next morning!
Made this for my girlfriend, who has a somewhat restricted diet. Made it exactly as pre the recipe, and she absolutely loved it.

I loved this chili. However I did make a couple changes. I used 2 28oz cans of crushed tomatoes instead of the whole tomatoes. I used 2 cans of kidney beans, 1 can of black beans and I omitted the corn just because my idea of chili doesn’t have corn. As it came together I was excited. The chili was fragrant and my boyfriend said it was perfect!

Super good chili--I cut the "hot" spices in half and then it was perfect. Question...does anyone know the size of a serving? As I'm logging my food I kind of need to know. The info says 391 cal in a serving but I can't find anything to tell me what size the serving is...

Excellent vegetarian chili! To tone down the heat a bit, I added 2 hearty spoonfuls of marscapone cheese...it toned down the heat (spicy) and added a creamy texture to the chili...Absolutely delicious!!
This is the best vegetarian chili I've ever made!
Delicious. Didn't have the chili peppers.

I have made this recipe a million times and it has never failed me. If you leave out the dairy accompaniments like cheese and sour cream it is an easy vegan dish that even meat-eaters love.

I add two secret ingredients:
-Not Beef bullion cubes
-Worcestershire sauce (though this has fish sauce in it so is not vegan)
Love it love it

I love the recipe but could see the balance was off for my tastes. I followed the recipe making these changes: I doubled the garlic and cumin, used 2 tsp (not TBLSP) oregano, 2 big rounded Tblsp chili powder, only 1 12 oz pkg of veggie burgers, 1 14.5 oz can fire roasted diced tomatoes (I don't like chili too tomato-y), and ONE seeded jalepeno. This made a normal-sized amount and was still very hot. If you want it less hot, use 1/2 jalepeno without seeds. I also needed to add about 1/2 cup water as it was so thick. I put a blop of sour cream on top with chopped fresh cilantro. It was delicious! A little grated cheese, avocado, and a few crushed tortilla chips on top would be nice too. This is a wonderful recipe to tweek to your or your family's tastes.

I’ve tried lots of veggie chili recipes, and this is by far my favorite! I make it with homemade seitan ground burger, and I use veg broth instead of oil. I also sometimes add cocoa and instant coffee and msg. It’s so yummy, and it makes a huge pot! I serve garnished with red onion, cilantro, and extra jalapeño. 

Thanks for a great recipe!

The absolute Best vegetarian chili recipe. Hands down. My significant other is a vegetarian and I was trying to figure out something wholesome and savory to make him this past winter. When I say he absolutely loved this chili it’s not an understatement! I loved it and I’m not a vegetarian! This one has become a staple in our lives.

The name says it all! I've tried different chilis and this is the one I liked the best. I made it once, a couple of months ago, and am about to go back to WalMart to buy ingredients to buy again. I recommend it - even if you're not vegetarian.

I embellished this chili with Impossible meat, Beyond Beef and No Evil Foods "Stallion" Italian sausage. Also doubled up on the onion, and substituted a red pepper for one of the greens.
Although I like garbanzos, I think next time, I might keep to kidneys and black beans.
It came out absolutely fantastic!
Definitely the best chili I ever made.
Omg it was sooo good
My first vegan meal and it came out great. i went a little heavy on the jalapenos but after a couple of days, it wasn't so bad. I will make this again. Even my meat eaters were impressed.

Great recipe - easy to substitute if you are missing an ingredient. I used canned jalapeños bc I did not have any fresh. I used crumbled up veggie burgers bc I did not have crumble. I did not include garbanzo beans - had none. Used sweet bell peppers as I did not have any regular green bell peppers. STILL delicious!!

My partner, our roommate, and I all thought this was a delicious and hearty recipe. I only used one bag of veggie crumbles and used frozen corn instead of canned. Kept the spices as written. It does get spicier as leftovers, but it’s so good it might not last that long.
This was a true crowd pleaser. Black beans don’t agree with my hubby so eliminated them. This was our tailgate dish after snowshoeing and everyone loved it!

This is a delicious recipe! I found myself without any crumbles and used two Soyrizo tubes? Not sure what to call them. The aromatics were "sauted" in the soyrizo with about a tablespoon of oil. My family is not vegetarian and no idea that there was not any meat in the chili. It came out a lot spicier than anticipated, jalapenos were super hot - the way my son and I like it. This recipe is a keeper!
Great recipe that I’ve made a few times.
I’ll make this again but will cut the spices in half. Way to hot for me.
Just finished making this, and wow! This is the best chili I've ever made. Such a great recipes and the only thing I added was some red crushed pepper flakes. Thanks for the great recipe!

DELICIOUS!!! My husband was skeptical given all the beans (he believes “real chili” doesn’t have beans), but he absolutely inhaled it. We didn’t miss “the meat” because Beyond “meat is a great substitute. Perfect spice level. Thanks for adding another meatless option to our dinner repertoire!
Very tasty. I doubled it and have quite a lot now....
This is a go too!!

This was delicious, especially as leftovers a couple days later! The flavors definitely enhance with time. Instead of 3 28 ounce cans of crushed tomatoes, I only used 2 and added a 15 oz can of diced tomatoes. Turned out to be a perfect consistency this way since I didn’t want a soupy chili. I also only used 1 package of beef crumbles plus about 2 cups of cooked quinoa (added towards the end). So hearty and filling, especially topped with a spoonful of sour cream!
Really really good! Best next day.
This is a wonderful recipe! For those with less heat tolerance, I would bring the chili powder down from 1/4 cup to 1 or 2 tablespoons. It’s very good either way!

It truly is the greatest! I am new to vegetarian dishes, and I seriously doubted that I would be able to get past the veggie crumbles, but man oh man! I cut the recipe in half (as it makes a heaping amount as is), Served with cornbread. Hubby gobbled it up- he has no idea it’s vegetarian-lol. Adding this to my regular rotation 4 sure!

First off, sweet mother of spicy! 

I've made this a few times now and admittedly, I add meat. Regardless of the meat part, this is truly one of the best chili's I've had (not a connoisseur, love chili). As noted, it is quite spicy. I have no trouble with it once I add cornbread, sour cream, and cheese, but my three year old absolutely could not manage it. This last round I cut all spicy items except the chili seasoning and the green chilies. Gave him a glass of milk to cover what was left of that bite. 

This past batch also I threw on the smoker for a lovely addition, which begs me to note that paprika could make a nice addition - haven't tried it. Again, still amazing!

I'm not sure I'd label this the best in the world, though it was good. I made it as written (minus the jalapeno as we serve our toddler the same things we are eating) and found the oregano to be incredibly overpowering. I would cut that in half next time and probably eliminate the bay leaf to see how it is. 

Otherwise, it was very hearty, made plenty for leftovers and got good reviews from our guests, who are used to eating beef or chicken chili. We served with sourdough bread.
Lives up to its name! We like spicy and this was the perfect amount of heat and flavor.
I like hot and this chili was too hot. I will make this again.

I made this last night, and it was absolutely delicious. I do however feel it wasn’t as spicy as I would like it to be. That’s with me doubling the spices. I just chopped up another fresh jalapeño and topped it. Will definitely try it again!
Omg yum! Has just the right amount of heat with just one jalapeño. Used two boca burgers and added about 1/2 cup water. Delicious, probably the best batch of chili I have ever made!

I love this recipe. It has been a weekly fall/winter recipe that I pull out for all my picky eaters. It is super easy to make and extremely delicious. You can omit the sour cream and cheese topping to make it vegan. I usually put less chilli powder to appeal to all taste buds. Try this recipe, you will not be disappointed!

I make this all the time and love it, but I change it to 1 package of veggie crumbles, and 1 28oz can of crushed tomatoes. Even then I usually end up freezing some of the leftovers. I can't imagine making this with 3 28oz cans of tomatoes. It wouldn't fit in my biggest pot, and we'd have leftovers for weeks.
Really good!
Waste of expensive veg crumbles. Agree with other review: just tomatoes and powdered chili flavor, can’t taste anything else. Goes to show that you can’t count on the stars on this site,

Turned out awesome! I only used one jalapeno and used a canned tomato/green chile mix instead of all 3 cans of tomatoes and 2 cans of chiles. I used Impossible beef and I also added a small amount of some McCormick chili seasoning. Two meat eaters and two vegetarians served. Four happy stomachs! Will make again.
This chili was good, but I much prefer a recipe with fresh ingredients rather than all canned.

This chili just didn't do it for my boyfriend and me. Even with 1/4 cup of chili powder, it did not taste anything like chili. I followed the recipe pretty closely - I only had one jalapeño so it wasn't too spicy like it was for others, and I skipped the vegan ground beef because there was plenty of protein from all the beans.

I think the issues for us were the full TABLESPOON of salt, which I was very wary of but decided to trust the recipe and added it anyway. The other issue was the THREE 28oz cans of tomatoes. I've never seen that much canned tomato in a chili recipe before but again, decided to trust it and added them all anyway. The resulting flavor (for us) was just way too tangy/sweet tomato-y flavor from too much tomatoes, plus much too much saltiness from the whole TABLESPOON of salt. The beans I used were unsalted too, and I'm glad I didn't add any frozen veggie grounds because the net saltiness would have made it completely inedible. 

I'm trying to figure out how to fix this so it's not a misery to eat for the rest of the week, as I'm not going to throw it out. I think I will basically just greatly increase the servings by adding a lot of water and much more beans with their bean juice to keep it thick enough.

It was a super pretty bowl of chili, but I this is not a good chili recipe, much less the "Best" in the world. Sorry.

Awesome vegetarian chili! I don’t think anyone would know there isn’t any meat in this! Spicy and delicious! I followed this recipe exactly, except I only used 2 TBSP chili powder because my chili spice is fiery hot! Yum! I’m thrilled to find a vegetarian recipe (my adult children are all vegetarians) that my husband and I love too! We will definitely make this again. Thanks!

I did some alterations and I thought this was delish. I did not use the protein crumbles, oregano, bay leaves, cumin or jalapenos. Only had garbanzo beans - 2 cans. I did add the liquid from one can of green chili peppers. We topped it with grated cheddar cheese and sour cream. We will have this again.

I followed the directions completely and was very disappointed. It seriously lacked spice and flavor. I had to add more salt, 1 TBS garlic powder, 1 tsp cayenne pepper, more jalapeño, and 4 oz. of tomato paste because it was so runny. Next time I make it I am going to follow my own edits and also take out the celery (did nothing), switch garbanzo beans with pinto beans, and add some orange bell pepper.

I did not read comments beforehand. However, I disagree about the specimens and think it’s spot on. I made as written and it was thick so I added about 10 ounces of water and it was just right. Love this!
This was great! I am a “carnivore” trying to transition to healthier plant-based

First off, THIS RECIPE IS AMAZING. I definitely think the spice level varies based off of how spicy the Jalapenos and Green Chiles you use are. I mixed in a little chipotle and smoked paprika to my chili powder seasoning, only used one package of boca veggie crumbles, and topped the whole thing off with some veggie broth. I also drained and rinsed the beans, and drained the corn. HOLY COW this is freaking delicious. I did end up using canned whole tomatoes, but just broke them up a bit with the spoon as it was simmering. 10/10 will make again. Thank you!

Excellent!!! My husband is eating it before it is, technically, done by heating/simmering for a while! Didn’t have on hand so I didn’t use - jalapeño peppers, oregano, garbanzo beans, corn. I used 2 regular cans of chili beans (red) with sauce, threw in 2 cans of drained Black beans (were drained in prep for another meal, but decided to add here and glad I did). Did use parsley, 1/2 tbsp. Turmeric, half the chili seasoning indicated here, and in addition to large can of crushed tomatoes, added a can of seasoned diced tomatoes I had. This was so good and tasted so fresh.... apparently there will be none for tomorrow as my hubby is on his 4th serving In an hour- I’m not sure I’ll get to have some for tomorrow!

This is legitimately the best chili recipe ever. No, I don’t mean the best vegan chili recipe. It’s just so happens to be vegan. I loved this so much and shared it with my family who don’t believe it’s a meal if there’s no meat, and everyone loved it. It’s incredibly well seasoned, and I didn’t have to tinker or adjust anything. This is just a darn good recipe.
Great Recipe!

Really great recipe, but there are a few things I'll change when I make it again.

Definitely will be keeping the bay leaves whole and fishing them out before serving. My instinct told me to do that, but I followed the recipe to the t and those leaves do *not* soften, even when crumbled and simmered for hours.

As with all chili, this definitely benefitted from simmering for longer, which helped flavor, consistency and texture for me. (Ended up simmering on low heat for about 2 hours.)

My last note is on spice level - I see a few reviews that claim this is mind blowingly spicy, but mine turned out really tame (great for kids who aren't ready to have their tastebuds blown to bits yet, but a tad underwhelming for me). Spice level is definitely going to depend on your jalapeños, and next time, I'll be adding more.
Delicious! I added some fresh spinach to it for the last 5 mins or so of cooking. So good!
I have been making this chili recipe for years, and it’s always a big hit (even for meat eaters). I received 3rd place in a chili cook off, and no one knew it was vegetarian until after I won.

I absolutely loved it! A tad too spicy though, so next time, and believe me there will be a next time, I will cut the chili powder by half. My Puerto Rican husband loved it but I am not accustomed to that much spice! ;) What a great recipe!!!!

item.name: The Best Vegetarian Chili in the World
